_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1) Installation Description

Defense Supply Center Richmond, located along the I-95 corridor in southern Chesterfield County, Va., has been a consistent, dependable supplier of quality goods and services to those defending freedom around the world since it was activated in 1942.  
Designated as the lead center for aviation within the Defense Logistics Agency, the center serves within the DoD supply-chain as the primary source of supply for the nearly 850,000 repair parts and operating supply items. While these items and parts have an extremely wide range of applications, our core mission is to supply products with a direct application to aviation.  These items include a mix of military-unique items supporting over 1,300 major weapons systems and other items readily available in the commercial market.  

With over 600 acres and approximately 120 warehousing, utility and administrative buildings totaling over 6.7 million square feet, however, Defense Supply Center Richmond is host for a number of other Department of Defense, federal and state organizations. The largest of these tenants are the 350-acre Defense Distribution Depot Richmond Virginia; the Defense Distribution Mapping Activity; the Virginia Army National Guard vehicle maintenance activity, and the Defense Reutilization and Marketing Office. The center and its tenant activities employ nearly 3,000 civilians, service members and contractor personnel, whose mission is to provide critical material support across the Department of Defense and other federal agencies, including NASA.

2. Types of Chemicals and Processes Present at DSCR

Although ozone-depleting substances form a substantial proportion of chemicals stored at DSCR, many other chemicals are present in significant quantities.  (Note that ozone-depleting substances are typically not regulated by the Risk Management Program (RMP) rule.)  Among these chemicals are hydrochloric acid, nitric acid, chlorine, acetylene, hydrogen, propane, formaldehyde, hydr

ofluoric acid, and ethylene oxide, and engine starting fluid (ethyl ether).  All of these substances are regulated by the RMP rule as either toxic or flammable substances. However, storage quantity of chemicals like chlorine, nitric acid, propane, formaldehyde and ethylene oxide remain below the respective RMP thrshold.

Other than storage of ozone-depleting substances, the Defense Distribution Depot performs an important function the reclamation and refurbishing of ODS and inert gases (such as oxygen, argon, and nitrogen).  While the ODS are recovered, inert gases are bled to the atmosphere.  After the ODS have been reclaimed, the empty cylinders are cleaned, tested, and re-certified (or rejected) by persons qualified by the Bureau of Explosives.  This process is known as the refurbishment of the ODS cylinders.

For the RMP update, not only was the storage of materials and the refurbishment of containers investigated but, several other activities which occur at the installation were investigated from the standpoint of the RMP rule.  Building 80 houses the Equipment Maintenance Branch, consisting of Material Handling & Equipment and the Automotive and Heavy Equipment shop.  While there are many activities here that involve the use of chemicals, such chemicals are typically not covered by the RMP rule.  Examples of the chemicals handled are paints and solvents (in the automotive paint booth), degreasing solvents (mainly containing naphtha), new and spent engine oils, batteries, tires, and other materials generally associated with vehicle maintenance.  Similar operations are being conducted over at the Virginia Army National Guard Facility.  The results of the investigation determined that there are no chemicals present in Building 80, or over at the Virginia Army National Guard facility which the RMP Program would apply.

3. Distribution and Warehousing of Materials

Once a substance arrives at DSCR, the substance is inventoried; a stock number is assigned, and in tu

at DSCR, possibility of storing these chemicals above the RMP threshold can not be ruled out. Therefore, predictive reporting has been done for these chemicals. All the reported substances directly involve the warehouse storage operations of DSCR.  A list of these processes, along with their storage locations and quantities (predictive or actual) of each regulated substance is given below.
Chemical                 Warehouse     Location    Quantity             Threshold 
                                                     Stored (lb)       Quantity (lb)
Hydrochloric Acid          13         Bay 6         135,575(predictive)   15,000
Hydrochloric Acid          13         Bay 7         125,570(predictive)   15,000
Hydrochloric Acid          13         Bay 9         29,725 (predictive)   15,000
Hydrochloric Acid          13         Bay 10        84,825 (predictive)   15,000
Hydrofluoric Acid          13         Bay 6          1,000 (predictive)    1,000
Hydrogen                   95         Bay 2         10,000 (predictive)   10,000
Engine Starting             8         Bay 1         10,000 (predictive)   10,000
Engine Starting             8         Bay 2         10,000 (predictive)   10,000
Acetylene                  95         Bay 3        11,250                 10,000

A worst case scenario analysis was conducted on all processes that are subject to the rules.  For each regulated chemical in a process this analysis involved:

1) Determining the largest quantity of the regulated substance that can be released from the process in a 10-minute period;
2) Applying passive mitigation factors (such as those created by releases in enclosed spaces) to reduce the quantity that escapes into the outdoor environment;
3) Estimating the area of impact (represented by a circle, with the radius being the distance up to which there could be adverse impacts on public receptors);
4) Estimating the number of people offsite and identifying environmental receptors offsite that would be

adversely impacted by an accidental release of the chemical; and
5) Determining if the process has been involved in any accidental releases during the past five years that resulted in injuries, deaths, evacuations, and other similar emergency situations offsite, or damage to the environment.

The analytical procedures outlined above were applied to each of the processes listed above.  The results showed that none of the processes has the potential for off-site impacts.  Furthermore, none of these processes has been involved in any accidental releases during the past five years that resulted in emergency situations or damage to the environment.  Because DSCR is coordinating its emergency response program with local responders, these results indicate that all processes belong to Program Level 1.

Containers of propane, acetylene, and chlorine are received in the open-storage area, these containers are generally considered to be empty and the amount remaining inside the cylinders is marginal.  

DSCR also receives substances which are designated for redistribution to other supply centers in the Defense Logistics Agency.  These are stored in various locations throughout the Depot.  The following is a list of primary storage locations in the Depot.

4. Data Management and Availability of Storage Records

Because of the large number of items and materials that pass through

DSCR, and because of the large volumes of these items and materials, computerized databases were essential to reviewing the installation's inventories.  The Depot has a database known as the Distribution Standard System (DSS).  This system allows data to be sorted by materials, stock number, storage location, hazard code, available balance, and other data fields.  This database was invaluable in identifying RMP-regulated chemicals present at the Depot, their location, and the quantities in which they are being stored.

5. Emergency Response Program

An emergency response program is currently being implemented at DSCR.  The Fire Prevention and Protection Division (the Fire Department) at DSCR follows written procedures for emergency response notification and coordinates activities related to fire, rescue, and hazardous material response.  A memorandum of understanding (MOU) between DSCR and the County of Chesterfield, VA has been signed.  Mutual Aid agreements for assistance (fire protections, spill response, and medical assistance) are established with the Chesterfield County Fire Department.  Members of the LEPC attend and conduct training exercises and DSCR personnel participate in the training sessions.

6. Processes Subject to the RMP Rule

As of May 18th, 2009 there were 5 substances stored at DSCR that are subject to EPA's RMP rules.  These 5 substances are Â¿ (1) Acetylene, (2) Hydrochloric Acid, (3) Hydrogen, (4) Hydrofluoric Acid and (5) Engine Starting Fluid (Ethyl Ether). At the time of verification only acetylene was stored in a quantity that exceeded the RMP threshold. The other four substances either were stored in a quantity that is below the RMP threshold (Hydrogen, Engine Starting fluid and Hydrofluoric Acid) or the concentration of the chemical (Hydrochloric Acid) stored at the time is less than the required concentration to allow these chemicals to be categorized as an RMP chemical.
